title-group.article-title: Autoparametric interaction in a double pendulum system

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on Parametric Excitation: Applications in science and engineering

abstract.p: This article investigates a four-degree-of-freedom mechanical model comprising a horizontal bar onto which two identical pendula are fitted. The bar is suspended from a pair of springs and the left-hand-side pendulum is excited by means of a harmonic torque. The article shows that autoparametric interaction is possible by means of typical external and internal resonance conditions involving the system natural frequencies and excitation frequency, yielding an interesting case when the right-hand-side pendulum does not oscillate, but stays at rest. It is demonstrated that applying the standard method of multiple scales to this system leads to slow-time and subsequently steady-state equations representative of periodic responses; however, in common with previous findings reported in the literature for systems of four or more interacting modes, global solutions are not obtainable. This article then concentrates on discussing a proposed new modification to the method of multiple scales in which the effect of detuning is accentuated within the zeroth-order perturbation equations and it is then demonstrated that the numerical solutions from this approach to multiple scales yield results that are virtually indistinguishable from those obtained from direct numerical integration of the equations of motion. It is also shown that the algebraic structure of the steady-state solutions for the modified multiple scales analysis is identical to that obtained from a harmonic balance analysis for the case when the right-hand-side pendulum is decoupled. This particular decoupling case is prominent from examination of both the original equations of motion and the steady-state solutions irrespective of the analysis undertaken. This article concludes by showing that the translation and rotation of the bar are, in this particular case, mutually coupled and opposite in sign.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Autoparametric interactions at their simplest involve two systems which interact with a 2 : 1 ratio between two principal natural frequencies, and are arranged such that the forced vibration response of one element parametrically excites the other. The systems are coupled in a non-linear way, which together with frequency tuning, profoundly influences the actual response. Thus, under prescribed autoparametric (internal) resonance conditions, large exchanges of energy between the systems can occur.

There have been many studies concerned with the beneficial use of the effects of non-linear, autoparametric interactions in structures undergoing forced vibrations. A significant number of them have dealt with different design concepts and analyses of autoparametric vibration absorbers. This type of absorber acts as a secondary system by autoparametric interaction with a primary system, and limits or diminishes its response by soaking up its energy. A beam–pendulum system which exhibits this type of autoparametric interaction was introduced by Sevin1 in 1961. The same system was also considered by Struble and Heinbockel2 in 1963 and they determined the conditions for appreciable energy transfer between the pendulum and beam modes during free vibration. Haxton and Barr3 investigated the effectiveness of an autoparametric vibration absorber consisting of a massless cantilever beam carrying a concentrated mass at its free end, where this secondary absorber system was attached to a harmonically excited lumped primary mass. This secondary system has since been replaced by different alternatives: pendulum-type elements4–16 and a structure filled with a liquid.17,18 Flexible structures (mainly beams) have also been considered as primary systems, with a secondary system involving a coupled beam,19–21 a pendulum22 and a spring–mass system.23 These studies have investigated deterministic problems, i.e. those with harmonic excitation, which is also the type of excitation considered in this article. However, autoparametric interactions in structures excited randomly have also been widely investigated and the interested reader is referred to Cartmell7 and Tondl et al.8 for more details.

All these systems are mathematically modelled by a set of coupled, non-homogenous ordinary differential equations with quadratic non-linearities,24 and are similar to those describing the forced response of many other elastic and dynamical systems with multi-modal interactions, such as arches, composite plates, shells, vessels constrained to pitch and roll,25,26 and atomic force microscopes.27

In this article, a system of two pendula and an interconnecting rigid bar which can oscillate vertically and rotationally is proposed in an attempt to create a scenario with autoparametric interaction. Forcing one pendulum generates an interaction with the interconnecting beam and the other pendulum, causing a ‘cascade effect’, exciting it in a cascade of resonances and yielding interesting non-linear phenomena. The phenomenon of in-phase and out-of-phase synchronisation problems for forced rotating pendula coupled to an oscillating rigid body is considered in studies,28–30 with a view to achieving different body motions. However, neither the physical systems nor the equations of motion analysed in studies28–30 and those of this article are identical. The system studied herein is shown to possess four active degrees of freedom as considered, and these are defined in terms of Lagrangian generalised coordinates. The equations of motion are derived formally and then an approximate solution based on the standard form of the perturbation method of multiple scales31 is sought from the steady-state conditions that are assumed. It is found in this problem that global solutions cannot be readily obtained from the slow-flow equation which result from application of the standard method of multiple scales, particularly for the detuned cases that are of primary interest in practice,21,32 and so this provides a vehicle for a deeper investigation into the approach taken, from which a modified method emerges. It is shown that for the case examined this modified approach to standard multiple scales generates global numerical solutions which are virtually indistinguishable from those obtained from harmonic balance and direct numerical integration of the equations of motion. The solutions obtained illustrate autoparametric interaction and the interesting consequential behaviour when no energy goes to the right-hand-side pendulum and this pendulum does not oscillate.

sec.title: Mechanical model
sec.p:
The mechanical system comprises a square-section horizontal bar of mass M pivoted on a very low friction bearing at its centre. The outer race of this bearing is mounted on a linear bearing allowing rotation of the bar around the axis that is perpendicular to the bar and passes through its centre. In addition, this bearing is mounted on a slider that enables the bar to perform vertical translation, too. Two springs of stiffness k are equi-positioned at points A and B at distance l from the centre, as shown in Figure 1. The bar overhangs on each side such that the overall half-length of the bar is lr. Each pendulum is identical, and for simplicity we assume that the mass m within each pendulum is effective as a lump at each end of the pendulum the length of which is lp. Generalised coordinates are assigned to the system representing vertical translation of the bar by y, rotation of the bar about the translating centre through φ, rotation of the left-hand-side pendulum through ψ and rotation of the right-hand-side pendulum through θ, all as defined in Figure 2. It is assumed that the rotations through φ are small so that points A and B in Figure 1 just move vertically. The system is excited by means of a harmonically oscillating torque applied to the left-hand-side pendulum as defined in Figure 2. The assumption of high-quality bearings helps to vindicate the assumption later of classical linear viscous damping. sec.title: Steady-state response
sec.p: The steady-state response corresponds to the condition in which the slowly varying amplitudes and autonomous phase angles are assumed to be static (33) which yields (34(a) to (c))
Finally, based on equations (32(a) to (h)), (33) and (34(a) to (c)), a set of algebraic equations defining the steady-state response can be derived (35(a) to (h))

Equations (32(i)) and (35(a) to (h)) represent the results of the multiple scales analysis for this four-degree-of-freedom system but, as was stated in Cartmell and Roberts21 and also in Bux and Roberts,32 solution of systems of steady-state algebraic equations by means of conventional multiple scales for autoparametric systems of more than three coupled degrees of freedom can be elusive, and in fact were stated to be unobtainable in Cartmell and Roberts21 and Bux and Roberts.32 In the case of the equations here, global numerical solutions which are properly representative of the system have not been forthcoming, particularly for cases of non-zero detuning parameter values. In order to make progress with this, it is necessary to investigate the methodology behind the standard method and consider if it offers all that is necessary in this situation. In the standard method,31 where the zeroth-order perturbation equations are homogeneous, the numerical contributions to the zeroth-order perturbation solutions do not vary. This is because they oscillate at the natural frequencies and these are fixed. However, the amplitudes appearing in the solutions to the zeroth-order perturbation equations (a, b, c, f in equation (28(a) to (d))) are obtained from solving either the slow-time modulation equation (equation (32(a) to (i)) in this case), or the steady-state algebraic equations (equations (32(i)) and (35(a) to (h))), noting that either will do for the sake of argument, and those amplitudes will change with detuning because of the explicit presence of the detuning parameters in both sets of equations. Hence, in the standard method, the effect of detuning on the zeroth-order perturbation equation solutions is only through the modifications of the amplitudes by detuning, which feeds back in from solving the modulation equations or the steady-state equations for those amplitudes. This demonstrates that the effects of detuning within the system are largely retained to first-order perturbation and above using the standard method, and yet this is numerically inconsistent with anything other than the smallest deviation from perfectly tuned resonance conditions. Indeed, sizeable detuning parameter values, as encountered routinely in experimental systems, necessarily contravene these implied limitations completely. In the following section, a modification to the standard method of multiple scales is offered, and results are obtained which compare favourably with the method of harmonic balance and direct numerical integration.

sec.title: Application of the modified method of multiple scales
sec.p: In this section, a modified version of the method of multiple scales is presented in order to rationalise the anomaly between restricting detuning parameter effects to first-order perturbation and above and the realistic values of detuning encountered in practice. The initial step is to define the detuning parameters with respect to the differences of the squares of the natural frequencies and the frequency of excitation, as follows (36(a) to (c))

It can be seen that the squared natural frequencies are replaced with squared excitation frequencies and a residual term involving the detuning parameters and the excitation frequency. This is an approximation because the rest of the square is missing but as that missing term involves the detuning parameter squared, it potentially renders the term too small to be included anyway (strictly this is indeed the case because the missing term includes ɛ2 so this approach is consistent with the rest of the analysis). The net effect of this is to make the zeroth-order perturbation equation functions of the excitation frequency and not the natural frequencies; please see equation (38(a) to (d)) which follows on from the appropriately revised equations of motion (22(a) to (d)). Equations (22(a) to (d)) transforms to (37(a) to (d))

Returning momentarily to the frequency relationships given in equations (36(a) to (c)), it can be seen that for perfect tuning cases, when the detuning parameters are zero, the residual terms on the right-hand sides of equations (36(a) to (c)) are zero and so the solutions to the zeroth-order perturbation equations will oscillate at the exact natural frequencies, as they should. In the case of non-zero detuning, the solutions to the zeroth-order perturbation equations will oscillate at the excitation frequency and therefore there will be an effect from detuning introduced directly at the zeroth-order perturbation level. This can easily be seen by examining equations (38(a) to (d)).

Next, a pair of time scales and their derivatives are all introduced in accordance with equations (23(a) to (d)) and the solutions are once again expressed in power series form (24(a) to (d)). Grouping terms to order ɛ0 yields the zeroth-order perturbation equations (38(a) to (d)) and the first-order perturbation equations result from grouping terms to order ɛ1: (39(a) to (d))

The detuning parameters explicitly appear in the right-hand sides of the first-order perturbation equations in each case. The general solutions to the zeroth-order perturbation equations are again assumed to be of complex form (40(a) to (d)) where A, B, C and F are the unknown functions, which can be expressed in polar form (28(a) to (d)). Clearly, it is now possible to get two detuning variation effects on the zeroth-order perturbation solutions, which are (a) the effect of the alteration in excitation frequency and (b) the effect of the alteration of amplitudes a, b, c, and f due to detuning coming through the feeding back of those amplitudes from solving the modulation or steady-state equations. This is more consistent with the realistic numerical values for detuning encountered in practice. These equations do not contain time explicitly and so a transformation into an autonomous system is not required at this stage, and it is possible to proceed to obtain equations for steady-state responses and then to examine these numerically.

sec.p:

It should be noted that the bar is assumed to be a 1″ (25.4 mm) square-section stock bar of 6082T6 or 2014T4 aluminium alloy of mass per unit length 1.76 kg/m. The pendula are identical in geometry and mass. The results from the numerical integration of the equations of motion (the red dots) do not predict stable solutions within the jumps, as is commonly encountered and expected, nor do they appear to exist at and around the externally resonant point, despite the results from the modified multiple scales method suggesting otherwise. This also accords with frequent observation. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: It has been shown in this article that a pair of pendula, fitted symmetrically along the length of a translating and rotating bar, with one pendulum excited by means of a harmonically oscillating torque superficially appear to be coupled through the equations of motion but that there is also a case through which the two pendula decouple mathematically. This can be observed in the equations of motion and also in the steady-state solutions obtained by means of multiple scales or harmonic balance. It has also been shown that although the standard method of multiple scales allows the derivation of slow-time and then steady-state equations which represent the periodic dynamics of the system, global numerical solutions for the system are not forthcoming. This is substantiated by earlier findings in the literature for larger coupled systems (of four or more generalised coordinates or modes). Thus, in order to solve this long established problem, an alternative approach to the standard method of multiple scales is offered in which the relationships between the excitation and natural frequencies are differently expressed (noting that no changes whatsoever are made to the physical relationships to which they refer) leading to zeroth-order perturbation solutions which contain explicit detuning information through frequency as well as through the amplitudes (which are obtained in the usual way through the slow-time or steady-state equation obtained from the first-order perturbation equations). This leads to a strengthening of the presence of detuning which is more in line with the numerical values obtained in practice, and which in turn leads to steady-state solution forms which are not only numerically tractable and convergent for all the cases examined, but which also cross-validate with the algebraic results of applying harmonic balance. Numerical validation is provided by means of comparison with the results of direct numerical integration of the equations of motion. In addition, the translational and rotational responses of the bar are shown to be mutually coupled and opposite in sign for the case when the right-hand-side pendulum decouples and does not oscillate. This is shown both algebraically and numerically.

A useful further development of this study would be to investigate the potential for agreement between the perturbation method and direct numerical integration for the case when the pendulum non-linearities are retained in addition to the quadratic coupling terms.

The article shows that the right-hand-side pendulum can decouple from the problem as it is stated here. It would be interesting to see if further developments of the problem, perhaps with additional degrees of freedom included for the interconnecting rigid body, would permit interaction with the right-hand-side pendulum. If this is shown to be the possible, then there is an interesting case for further studies of synchronisation based around this extended autoparametric system model. This will be followed up in future work.
